textContent:
Started with the BWF primer for a month. Went straight to the full workout table after skimming through the articles, and perfected technique along the way. Went for max suggested reps, except for pushups, of which I could only do 3x3-4 
Began 21/02/2024
Got sick, 6 days break from 08/03/2024 to 13/03/2024
Some days I didn't have acces to a pullup bar.
Tried different things, from 6 day full workout, to 6 day half workout, to 3 day full workout. No real conclusion, besides that some times I felt slight muscle soreness and some other times I didn't. Maybe it has something to do with proper technique, or otherwise it's just fatigue from training the same muscle multiple days in a row.

I can't yet see many visible changes, given my high body fat (BF), but I can tell that I've gotten stronger by just feeling my muscles or by doing exercises.


Diet:

Bulking from the beginning on a 300-500 kcal surplus. ~170g protein, the rest is carbs and fat. Ideally more carb calories than fat, but unfortunately it's usually the opposite.
I take a protein shake most days, sometimes with two scoops of whey (especially when I'm not home and can't guarantee I would hit mi protein intake otherwise). I don't particularly worry about what I eat at this stage, although I try to limit added sugars to a minimum, as it's quite addictive to me.


Motivators:

At two weeks my wrists stop hurting whem doing pushups. At first I needed to use parallel bars, but not anymore. I consider them to have been useful training wheels, for those struggling with wrist discomfort/pain.

Around the three week mark my GF noticed that my muscles were pretty hard when flexed, and my triceps and deltoid muscles were visibly getting bigger. My stamina and strength in the bed have also noticably improved.
Around that time, I also hit the BWF primer benchmark of 3x8 pushups with 1s holds when extended and retracted, the exercise I struggled with the most. This was a big payoff, as I kept myself from cheating myself by keeping good form at all times, and admitting defeat when I couldn't maintain it, even if it meant fewer reps than last time. This is the first time in my life my upper body is this strong relative to my weight.


Tips for motivation:

I try to keep my goal of doing fun calisthenics in mind (mainly gymnastics and rock climbing). I want to be able to do those, but can't without the proper foundations.
I find that the youtube algorithm really helps me keep my motivation going with all their recommendations (shorts and videos on recommended routines for different muscles, stretching exercises, diet tips, etc).
Of course, improving my looks is also an important motivator. I've always struggled with my man boobs and skinny arms, and would love to fix those


Progress video:

No shirt, blue pants on.
Leave on third shelf, first basket from right. Step 5 tiles back, pose 1 front, 2 side, 3 back arms down, 4 back arms up.


Indicators:

Started at 80kg, high BF.

1st 17/03/2024. 84,2kg, 20,5% BF.
title: Fitness notes
